On Aug. 21, businesses accepted the unionâ€™s demands. The strike broke the control of the Citizensâ€™ Alliance and encouraged workers in many other industries to organize. The Minneapolis strike is considered a pivotal moment in Teamsters and labor history. /end

The police violence stunned Minneapolisâ€™s working class, and other workers took part in strikes in protest. Minnesotaâ€™s governor declared martial law, called in the National Guard and arrested union leaders, but rank-and-file members held a mass rally demanding their release. /6

Fighting continued off and on until July 20, when a single truck drove to the market escorted by 50 armed policemen. A vehicle carrying picketers attempted to cut off the truck, and police opened fire on the vehicle and picketers in the surrounding area. Two strikers were killed and 67 wounded. /5

The union had shut down the Minneapolis market area, which was the scene of the fiercest fighting between strikers and police. Police beat strikers who tried to prevent scabs from unloading trucks. Newly deputized members of the Citizensâ€™ Alliance, an employersâ€™ group, also fought with strikers. /4

On May 16, 1934, Teamsters Local 574 initiated a strike against Minneapolis trucking companies, demanding union recognition, wage increases, shorter hours and the right to represent inside workers (those who didnâ€™t drive trucks). The strike shut down most trucking operations in the city. /3

Minneapolis was a non-union city, and business leaders had prevented unions from organizing. After a successful strike by coal drivers during the winter of 1933, however, the General Workers Local 574 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters union organized some 3,000 transportation workers. /2

#ResistanceRoots Today in history, 1934: Police fire on striking truck drivers during the Minneapolis Teamsters strike, killing two and wounding 67. It was the bloodiest day in the strike that began on May 16 and ended on Aug. 22, with periodic episodes of violence throughout the summer. /1
